titleStmt.title:
Mary the Cookmaid's
Letter to Dr Sherridan.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: BY DEAN SWIFT.
Well if I ever saw such another Man since my Mother bound my Head
You a Gentleman marry cum up I wonder where you was bred
I'm Sure such Words does not become a Man of your Cloth
I would not give such Language to a Dog faith and Troth
Yes you call'd my Master a Knave fie Mr SHERRIDAN tis a Shame
For a Parson who should know better things to come out with such a name
KNAVE in your teeth Mr SHERRIDAN tis both a Shame and a Sin
The DEAN my Master is an honester Man than you and all your Kin
He has more Goodness in his little Finger than you in your whole Body
My Master as a Parsonable Man and not a spindle Shank'd hoddy Doddy
And now whereby I find you would fain make an Excuse
Because my Master one day in Anger call'd you a Goose
Which and I am Sure I have been his Servant four years since October
And he never call'd me worse than Sweetheart Drunk or Sober
Not that I know his Reverence was ever concern'd to my knowledge
Tho you and your Come-Rouges keep him up so late in your Colledge
You say you will eat Grass on his Grave a Christian eat Grass
Whereby you now confess yourself to be either a Goose or an Ass
But that's as much as to say my Master should die before ye
Well well that's as God pleases and I dont believe that's a true Story
om.
om.
And so Say I told you so and you may go tell my Master what care I
And I dont care who knows it, it is all one to MARY
Every body knows that I love to tell the Truth and Shame the Devil
I am but a poor Servant but I think Gentlefolkes should be Civil
Besides you found fault with our Vittles one day that you was here
I remember it was upon Tuesday of all the Days in the Year
And SAUNDERS the Man says that you are always jesting and mocking
MARY says he (one day as I was mending my Master's Stocking)
My Master is so fond of that Minister that keeps the Scholl
I thought my Master a Wise Man but that Man makes him a Fool
SAUNDERS said I, I had rather than a Quart of Ale
He would come into our Kitchen and I would pin a dish Clout to his Tale
And now I must go and get SAUNDERS to direct this Letter
For I write but a bad Scrawl but my Sister Marget she writes better
Well but I must run and make the Bed before my Master comes from Prayers
And See now it Strikes Ten and I hear him coming up Stairs
Whereof I could Say more to your Verses if I could write written hand

And So I remain In a Civil way your humble Servant to Command
_MARY.
om.
